div.p: LOVE'S FRAILTIES: A COMEDY IN FIVE ACTS, AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR SHEPPERSON AND REYNOLDS, NO. 137, OXFORD STREET.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THOSE paſſages that are printed in Italics (not including the French) were omitted on the firſt repreſentation, one excepted, page 66, of which the words that then gave offence are diſtinguiſhed by capitals. They are thus pointed out that the reader, who in the heat of political zeal has not quite loſt his underſtanding, may examine what there is in them injurious to truth, or the good of mankind, and find it, if he can. In different times and under different feelings, it will appear aſtoniſhing that any one of theſe paſſages were ſuppreſſed, from any apprehenſion of political reſentment: but ſuch was the fact. That the one unwarily retained ſhould excite the anger which was teſtified is ſtill more aſtoniſhing. A ſentence ſo true as to have been repeated in a thouſand different modes: for all ſtrong moral truths are ſubject to ſuch repetition. A ſentence that, under a variety of forms and phraſeology, is proverbial in all nations. It ought however to be remembered, that the perſons offended, though violent, were few. Their intention doubtleſs was good: the ſame cannot be affirmed of their intellect.

Thoſe who are acquainted with German literature, and who have read the drama entitled, Der Deutſche Hauſvater, by the Baron von Gemmingen, will immediately perceive that the author has availed himſelf of various incidents and thoughts in that piece; though his fable, characters, and denouement are exceedingly different. Others, who wiſh to ſatisfy their curioſity but who cannot read German, may find a French tranſlation of that piece in volume VI. of a work entitled Nouveau Theatre Allemand, by M. M. Friedel and de Bonneville.

THE reaſons which have occaſioned the alteration of price in the preſent comedy ought to be ſtated to the public. The previous knowledge of men and manners, and the extraordinary efforts of ſtudy, time, and talents, which are neceſſary to produce a play that has but a chance of being ſanctioned by the town, are ſufficiently obvious. The labourer is worthy of his hire. In the beginning of the preſent century, the price of an octavo play was eighteen pence. Since that period, the price of paper has been doubled; the expence of printing is advanced in nearly the ſame ratio; and advertiſing, which now amounts to a conſiderable ſum, was then a burthen unknown. It has long been the complaint of the trade that the purchaſe of the copy-right, added to the above coſts, occaſioned plays to be a dangerous ſpeculation. The new tax on paper, in addition to all theſe, has made it impoſſible, at the former price, to reward authors, and afford the bookſeller a reaſonable hope of profit. Theſe conſiderations have induced an advance of price, at which it is preſumed no juſt reaſoner will take offence.

div.head: PROLOGUE.

lg.l: "PROLOGUES have long been plac'd, like little a,
"Before that great noun ſubſtantive a play:"
Not form'd of winged words, but wanting wings,
"Of common gender, half-no-meaning things:
"Like rag-fair robes, made up, with little ſkill,
"To ſuit farce, tragedy, or what you will:
"Mere taſteleſs bread-crumbs, only fit for ſtuffing:"
A cringing crew, and vilely prone to puffing:
Beggars, well ſatisfied, at any rate,
To feed on offals at the public gate:
"Or running footmen," ſent with whoop and hollo,
Types of the vapid things that are to follow:
Grace before meat, which, while the dinner cools,
Is twang'd by knaves, and liſten'd to by fools.
But let us take, nor waſte our little wit,
A ſingle theme, that may our purpoſe fit.
"Prologues are ſcouts, that ſkulk from poſt to poſt,
"And ſcour the field, to watch the adverſe hoſt.
"Heroes invincible! Left! Right! Front! Rear!
"Embattl'd ranks! ye thrill the ſoul with fear!"
Wadded with critic ſpleen (Pit) and prim'd with ire,
Charg'd to the muzzle, ready to give fire,
To ſlaughter ſome inclin'd, and ſome to ſleep,
"Lo ruthleſs veterans rang'd, intrench'd chin deep!
"Flanking this fearful centre in a ring, (Boxes)
"Gay knights and Amazons form either wing!
"Corps of reſerve (Gallery) drawn up in dread array,
"On yonder heights await the coming fray!"
But as you're ſtrong be juſt, in this fierce battle,
Ye godlike men of might, and maids of mettle!
Here let us pauſe: for, ah! 'tis but too true,
Caſſandra like, in black prophetic view,
I ſee the maſſacres that may enſue!
Wit, humour, character, are put to rout!
The prompter breathleſs, and the actors out!
Quibbles and clap-traps in confuſion run!
Slain is a ſentiment! Down drops a pun!
Nay plot himſelf, that leader far renown'd,
Oh ſhame! dare ſcarcely ſtand another round!
"How ſhall our general dare ſuch danger meet?
"Were it not better, think you, ſirs, to treat?
"War honours grant then, as he files away;
"So may he live and fight another day."

div.p: [For the ſubject of this Prologue, and the lines marked with inverted commas, the author is indebted to a literary friend.]

lg.l: AS ſome poor wand'rer, who with eager flight
Is homeward hurried by the approach of night,
Comes to the deep abyſs, o'er which is thrown
Trunk of old oak or wedge of unhewn ſtone,
Tremendous bridge! which he muſt venture o'er,
Braving the horrid gulph and cataract roar,
Slippery! abrupt! no hold, no ſtay, no truſt!
The firſt falſe ſtep is death! Yet croſs he muſt,
Safely on t'other ſide looks ſhivering back,
And palpitating views the dreadful track,
So ſtands the happy bard, from danger free,
And trembles at his own temerity!
Bold is the man, or little prone to fear,
Who hopes to write what's fit for you to hear;
Conſcious what ſplendid feaſts regale this ſtage,
Prepar'd by other bards, born of another age!
Oh Congreve! Otway! Shakeſpear! mighty ſhades!
Whoſe genius every realm of thought pervades,
Gifts ſuch as yours, alas! where ſhall we find?
Words that with living pictures fill the mind!
Extatic imagery! thoughts divine!
And volumes utter'd in a ſingle line!
But ah! of them and of their heav'nly lays
Fools to remind you, by preſumptuous praiſe!
Dropt be the ſacred veil we've raſhly dar'd to raiſe.
What can be done? Were will like wiſhing free,
Various and rich ſhould each freſh banquet be:
Emralds and pearls diſſolv'd in liquid gold,
Had we the alchymy, were yours tenfold!
Like thoſe poor Arabs who in deſerts live,
The little that we have we freely give.
Finding what may but chance to pleaſe your taſte,
We ſerve the morſel up with eager haſte:
Happy in this, you know our good intent,
And take in honeſt part what honeſtly is meant.

div.head: SCENE I. The Houſe of Sir GREGORY OLDWORT.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I WILL not hear you, Louiſa. In love yourſelf with a man deſtitute of rank and fortune, ought you to ſchool me?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: A man of family, brother, though not of rank.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Pennyleſs: a lieutenant in a marching regiment.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: But poſſeſſed of honour, worth, and virtue.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: And who has more honour worth and virtue than my Paulina?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: A painter's daughter, Charles.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: A divinity! Her beauty angelic, her mind godlike!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Thus we lovers rave. The world contains but one!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p:
Where is there another Paulina? Encumbered by the abſurdities of folly, diſguiſed by the
ridiculous trappings of faſhion, where ſhall the ſincere, the ſimple, the affectionate heart be found? I enter the tumultuous aſſemblies of the idle and all is vanity, all affectation, all incoherency. This hubbub of incongruous and deſpicable paſſions but maddens my mind: and, by the contraſt, irradiates the abode of peace and Paulina.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ah, Charles, you forget our dependent ſituation; our family.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Our fools and tyrants. An elder brother, whoſe rank wealth and power, inſtead of affording us protection, have been made the paſſports of folly and vice; and an uncle, whoſe benevolence is ſelf love; who has given us ſhelter only to make us ſlaves; at once a cynic and a ſenſualiſt; ſevere to others, indulgent to himſelf; arbitrary in principle, libidinous in practice.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Alas, too true! Sir Gregory pardons nobody's faults but his own.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Did he not ſuffer his ſiſter to languiſh and die in penury in a foreign land? And what was her crime? Marriage, with a man of a noble mind; but who had the misfortune to be poor and unprotected.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: 'Tis that makes me ſhudder! The very ſame fate is impending over our heads.

p.q: Let it fall; at leaſt on me. Injuſtice to myſelf ſhall not make me unjuſt to others.

Ay, but there's the queſtion. Your poor painter's daughter may, conſidering the indigence in which ſhe has been bred, be the phoenix you think her; but can you Charles honeſtly aver ſhe is the equal of Lady Fancourt?

Not to dwell on rank fortune
fame and power, which ſhe ſo eminently poſſeſſes and which ſurely are ſomething—

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Is the mind of Paulina equally cultivated; equally penetrating ſtrong and towering?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: More! More!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ah, Charles!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: By heavens, more!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Lady Fancourt is a woman of ten thouſand!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I grant it.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: She has conceived a partiality for you; Sir Gregory has diſcovered it, and is determined on the match.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: And I am determined it ſhall never take place.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: For my ſake, think again.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: At your requeſt, I have already been torturing Paulina and myſelf: I have not ſeen her for a week; an excruciating eternal week. But I will be guilty of this cruel injuſtice no longer.

p.q: Remember your own principles, Charles, remember truth. We muſt not with the avarice of egotiſm live for ſelf, but for ſociety. You have duties to mankind, for the fulfilling of which you ought not to be diſabled by the indulgence of paſſion.

I own it; and the doubts of what theſe duties are, haunt and perturb my mind inceſſantly, render me undecided, cauſe me every hour to form a thouſand contradictory plans, and, inſtead of making me active and firm, murder reſolution and torment me into reſtleſs ſuſpence.

Opinion is the ſlave of error, the
world is the ſlave of opinion, and we are the ſlaves of the world.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: 'Tis your ſituation, Louiſa, that rivets my ſhackles, which elſe I would break, and brave the world's injuſtice and an uncle's tyranny. But I know your affection for Mr. Compton, I am ſenſible of his worth, and I cannot dare not abandon you to the wretchedneſs I foreſee, ſhould I diſobey Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (In tears) Charles!—Your kindneſs is killing: I can endure any thing but that.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I do not deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I have deceived you.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: For this fortnight my heart has been burſting with a ſecret, which my tongue has not dared to utter.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Heavens!—I gueſs—I forebode—You are married?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Why then 'tis paſt—You have got the ſtart of me—I have heſitated, you have reſolved; and Paulina, the affectionate pure hearted noble minded Paulina muſt be ſacrificed, or poverty perſecution contempt and miſery muſt be the fate of all.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I am a ſelfiſh wretch, and deſerve the worſt that can befall me.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: No no—Where is your huſband?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Looking round) For heaven's ſake, beware.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Well well, where is Mr. Compton?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: On duty with his regiment in Yorkſhire, to which he was ſuddenly ordered, and as I ſuſpect by the management of Sir Gregory—

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Who not only threatens but acts.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: He has written to me concerning Mr. Compton, and with ſuch ſeverity! He has quite killed the little hope I had.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I expect his arrival from the country every minute. Diſperſe your gloom: be chearful.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: A ſmiling face with an aching heart is a painful taſk—

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: But now more than ever neceſſary. His preaching and his practice are ſo oppoſite that he dreads detection and hates ridicule. You have the art to keep him in ſome awe.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I had, but want the courage now to practice it.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Nay nay, but you muſt—Oh, Paulina!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Without) Why, William! James!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Here he comes!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Where are you all?

div.head: SCENE II. Enter Sir GREGORY OLDWORT.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Aſſuming chearfulneſs) You are welcome home, Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: So you ſay.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I hope you have had a pleaſant journey▪ ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (To a footman) Take this coat. Duſt enough! The roads are as crowded as the ſtreets; and have no leſs hurry, noiſe and inſolence.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: A mob is always unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: And the whole world is become a mob. Ah, what different beings were our brave anceſtors, the bold barons!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ay, uncle! How delightful it is to contemplate their venerable figures, in old Gothic cathedrals!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Kneeling in marble, with their huge helmets, long ſwords, alabaſter ruffs, grim beards, and gruff faces; that ſeem to bid you keep your diſtance, or damme! they will riſe and knock you down, as ſoon as they have done praying.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And yet, ſomehow, a little modiſh politeneſs, and delicacy—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I hate the words! They are outlandiſh, contraband, and were imported in ſome damned cargo of fans, muffs, fringed nightcaps, and chicken gloves.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I own it would be diverting to ſee a modern petit-maitre in a coat of mail!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Zounds! He would melt under it like a man of ſnow before the ſun! A coat of mail? A coat of pink tiffany! A degenerate—Ah!—I have not patience! A robuſt hearty fellow, that ſpeaks what he thinks, eats when he is hungry, and fights when he is angry, is called barbarian! horrid brute! And the ſight of ſuch a phenomenon would infallibly throw a whole aſſembly, men, women, and fiddlers, into hyſterics.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Aſide to Charles obſerving him in a reverie) Charles!—Where are your thoughts?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Where they ought never to be; yet there they always are!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: No, no; the diſeaſe has attacked the vitals! The blood of our nobles is contaminated. All rank, all order, all diſtinction is loſt! Dukes and jockeys, earls and hop-dealers, peers and pickpockets, all mingle, indiſcriminately, and hold their nightly orgies at a hazard table!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Calculation, uncle, is the wiſdom of the age.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p:
Yes, he is moſt learned who beſt knows the odds; and he moſt renowned, who
fleeces his fellows with the greateſt adroitneſs!—Have you ſeen Lady Fancourt today? (To Charles)

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: 'Tis too early, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: No, ſir! Had not you my commands, ſir?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I had.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: And how came they to be diſobeyed?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Becauſe commanding is leſs difficult than obedience.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (With ſeverity) Sir, if ever you expect any favour or countenance from me, go, this very day, and tomorrow, and every day, and aſſiduouſly pay your court to that lady. I'll hear no anſwer.

div.head: SCENE III. Sir GREGORY, Lady LOUISA.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I declare, uncle, you are ſo ſevere, you frighten one!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Sternly) Have you received my letter?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ay, that too was ſevere enough!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Madam—!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Mr. Compton is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Without rank, connexions, or eſtate.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: His heart and underſtanding—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (With great determination and ſeverity) If I hear another word concerning him, you ſhall quit this houſe and my protection for ever!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (After a ſtruggle reſuming her temper) Well; we all have our failings!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I would have you both beware!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: My brother and I are young; we have ſome excuſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Becauſe, being young and fooliſh, you neglect the advice, and diſobey the commands, of the experienced and wiſe.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Why, if the experienced and wiſe are as—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: As what?—What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Nay, don't be alarmed, uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I!—Alarmed?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I have heard—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What have you heard?

div.head: SCENE IV. Enter Footman and Mr. MUSCADEL.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Mr. Muſcadel. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: That the experienced and the wiſe have their frolicks!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide to Lady Louiſa) Huſh!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nothing more certain, Lady Louiſa. Sir Gregory himſelf is a proof in point.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I, ſir?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Or you are horribly belied.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I have heard the moſt whimſical ſtories—!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I inſiſt—! Such calumny, ſir—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: That you ſteal out by twilight, and, if you ſee a cap and apron in the ſquare, you hobble after with a—Hem! Hiſt! Pretty maid! Where are you going? Where do you live? Don't be in ſuch a hurry!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I! I!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: That you buy ſilk purſes by the dozen, and put five new half guineas into each, and that, for want of better converſation, you aſk every girl you can come up with if ſhe is a good ſempſtreſs, for you have always plenty of needle-work.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I! I needle-work!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I talk to young girls!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nay that you have been ſeen to attempt to kiſs them under your own lamps.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch malignity? I—!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: And that you preſs them by the hand, pat their cheeks, tweak their chins, and fondle them, as Lady Mary Muzzy does her fat lapdog.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: That you carry ſilk handkerchiefs, too, and ribbands, and oranges.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (With great anxiety and half whiſpering) Here's ſomebody coming!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I forgot to aſk, have you any further commands for me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: No, ſir. Begone!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: No, no; ſtay, Charles!—And that you—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Begone, ſir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: That you—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Begone, I ſay! [Exit Seymour.

div.head: SCENE VI. Sir GREGORY, Lady LOUISA, and Mr. MUSCADEL.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide) I'll never forgive him while I have breath!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What vexed, baronet?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Such malice, ſir, is inſufferable.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Well, be good humoured and I'll ſpare you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide) As a butcher does a ſheep.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p:
Afraid Charles ſhould hear? You muſt commit him to me, Sir Gregory. He has ſpirit and fire, though rather ruſticated; but my inſtructions, and a little polite varniſh, will ſoon diſplay
thoſe bold tints and original touches, which a bad light and a college education have obſcured.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: He has already profited by your leſſons, ſir.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Yes, Lady Fancourt, herſelf, made the ſame remark but yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Charles is become a favourite with her ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Nay, don't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Jealous? Ha, ha, ha! That is excellent! I jealous! Am I not an adept in all the delightful follies of faſhion? Do I not lead the mode, and make thoſe dear whims which are ridiculous in others graceful and captivating in me? Am I not in debt to all the town, in love with all the women, envied by all the men, ſtared at by the world, laughed at by the little, imitated by the great, hated by the awkward, and hooted by the mob? Have I not ruined fifty tradeſmen and five Jews? Nay, have I not been ruined myſelf theſe three years, and do I not live in as high a ſtyle as ever? Ha, ha, ha! I jealous! If I cannot pretend to a lady's favours, who can?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Well, well; if you are certain you are not jealous—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh very certain—But, now, tell me, ſeriouſly, Lady Louiſa—Do you think Charles is—a favourite?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: With Lady Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Muſcadel, I appeal to your own penetration. You are a man of wit and diſcernment.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Why—I own—Ha, ha, ha! What fooliſh thing, now, am I going to own?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: A thouſand—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: You may own; and have a thouſand to ſpare.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: No—No—I, of all others, I am the—the man of her heart.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I doubt it.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Seriouſly?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Seriouſly.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: No—No—'Tis impoſſible—Let us forget it.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Do; if you can.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Can? Ha, ha, ha! That is very good! Hay, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ay, ay; vapour away. Your character is pretty well underſtood.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: So much the better. People of merit loſe nothing by being known. Day-light or dark, a diamond will ſparkle.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And you, Mr. Muſcadel, always ſhine. Like a lamp-reflector, you abſolutely blaze us blind.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Sitting or ſtanding, riding or walking, I do every thing with a grace. See me take out my handkerchief, put on my gloves, pick up a fan, preſent a bouquet, dangle in my chair, loll in my chariot; the moſt trifling actions are made intereſting by my manner. Nay, I even ſleep like a gentleman.

p.q: I think, Mr. Muſcadel, it is now ſix years ſince you came to your eſtate?

You are right. It was a great epocha! My father died in the morning, I was in full poſſeſſion before noon, in the evening I had an aſſignation with a beautiful woman, was caught by the huſband in her bedchamber, appointed to exchange a ſhot with him at five the next morning, loſt half my fortune at White's in
the interim, met my man, lodged a bullet in his body, ſent an atteſted account of the affair to the papers, took poſt for Dover, and enjoyed a hearty ſupper, my bottle of Burgundy, a French chanſon d'amour, and a ſound ſleep, the next night at Calais.
While your father and the man you had wronged lay ſtretched on their bier!
Um—No: as it happened, the gentleman mended, in ſpite of me and the doctors: the news was ſent me, we became the beſt of friends, and in ſix weeks I had the pleaſure to wiſh him joy of his recovery.
Was it my fault that ſhe was handſome, and I irreſiſtible?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ha! You may well be a favourite with the ladies!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh, yes: I can't help it. No more can they. I have a ſmile for one, a nod for another, a wink for a third, a hem and a how do you do for a fourth, and ſhe who gets a ſqueeze of the hand from me thinks herſelf in heaven!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And you really have no fear of a rival, with Lady Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: A rival? Ha, ha, ha! Rival?—Charles is gallant—Her ladyſhip is polite—but—Oh, no▪ ſhe is too fond of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Paſt doubt.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: She told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: What, herſelf?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Herſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: With her own lips?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Lips? Ha, ha, ha! No; the lips often deceive; the eyes never.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Be not too confident; there are coquettes in the world.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I know it; I am one. How do you like me, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: You are a modern man of faſhion; a beau, whoſe characteriſtic it is to babble; though you know little of what you ſay, and leſs of what you mean.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: And you are a bully, of the old ſchool: a kind of walking machine, to grind down beef.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide) Baboon!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You are an old bachelor, too; and have been all your life preaching continence, and practicing—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Suddenly) Sir, I muſt beg you will not, any more, make free with my moral character.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Muſcadel! There is nothing of which Sir Gregory is ſo chary as his moral character.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Niece—!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Egad, it is very true: a fair character, like a fair ſkin, if cloſely inſpected, has a thouſand irregularities.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Significantly) Ay, like the purple bloom on a freſh gathered plum, it muſt be admired, not touched: if you handle it, you deſtroy its beauty—Don't you, uncle?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Your character and mine, baronet, are certainly very oppoſite.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Or I would hang myſelf! You pretend to wit; but, like bookſellers, you deal in what you don't underſtand.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! You are an eight day clock, wound up once a week; a fixed ſtar, that every fool knows where to find; an evergreen, always of
one colour: a pariſh clerk, whoſe whole vocabulary begins and ends in amen. I am a camelion; an Engliſh April-day; a comet, that always appears in a blaze, is the talk of the town, the terror of married men, and the admiration of the whole world! While everybody is enquiring whence it comes, how long it ſtays, where it goes, and when it returns?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: You affect ſingularity, Mr. Muſcadel.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: No: it is natural to me. We men of faſhion are always leading the canaille into abſurdities, purpoſely to laugh at them. We are a kind of Will with a wiſp; we glitter and entice the gazer into a bog, and there leave him.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Come, come; I muſt begone, to dreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ah! you are rare animals!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Meteors, Sir Gregory; which you terreſtrials may gaze at, but cannot reach: a kind of rainbow, the ſplendor of which everybody admires, but nobody can equal. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. The Painting Room of Mr. CRAIG.
div.stage: Pictures every where diſperſed, ſome hanging, ſome ſtanding on the ground. The furniture mean: Mr. Craig painting; Paulina at work, and ſinging.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I ONCE had a bird of my own!
It flutter'd and caroll'd right merrily;
I look'd, and I found it had flown:
Gone from me, ah woe, and ah weladay!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: "Poor warbler, while yet thou wert mine,
"I fed, and I kiſs'd, and I fondled thee;
"I never once knew thee to pine:
"Then why haſt thou left me: ah weladay?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: "I heard thy ſweet ſong with delight;
"Thy boundings and frolics gave joy to me;
"Nor wert thou confin'd in thy flight:
"Then why haſt thou left me: ah weladay?

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: "Now, rover, thy fate is to mourn:
"And I who ſo often have cheriſh'd thee,
"I too am deſponding, forlorn:
"Then why haſt thou left me: ah weladay?"

lg.head: V.
lg.l: This bird is the type, thou fond heart,
Of wand'ring which now is thy deſtiny.
Why wert thou ſo prone to depart;
Say why haſt thou left me, ah weladay?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Thanks, thanks, my Paulina! My palette in my hand, and thee ſinging beſide me, imagination glows, my ſoul expands, and my colours melt and mingle into life. My canvas talks to me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My heart beats whenever I ſee you happy.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ah could I but forget—Painting is a noble art! To practice it as an amateur would be my delight: but for ſale?—For hire?—I muſt not think of it!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh no; do not.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Every reſource exhauſted, doomed for years to work like a mechanic, receive pay—!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But where, ſir, is the diſgrace?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: What? A man of family!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: A man of virtue, ſir. What is family?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Thou muſt never marry, Paulina! No fellow of vulgar ſoul, with ſentiments as groſs as his occupation, and feelings as rude as his features, ſhall ever have thee.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But, if—?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: There is no if. I am degraded. Thy beauty and underſtanding might tempt a monarch: but I'm a painter! A hireling! A gentleman would contemn me, would expect me to fawn. I'll periſh firſt! Ay, and, dearly as I love thee, thou ſhalt periſh too!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Hah! Vat, I hear you ſing? Vat I hear you be merry, mitout morſel for bread to eat?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Nay, Nannette— (examining her baſket.)

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ay, ay; we'll ſing—like ſwans dying.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Taking his hand) Pray do not afflict yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Oh, no: I am merry. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dere! Dere be littel loaf for you, and littel loaf for you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And for yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: N'importe meeſelf; I don't a vant; I don't a care.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Woman! When did you ſee me eat and you faſt?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Eh bien! You don't a be ſo croſs, und I eat mit you den.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ay, ay; we'll ſhare. Hay, Paulina?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: To the laſt morſel.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Why that's my own girl.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Shall we repine?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Not at—? Well, well; we won't.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: There is not a ſhower that falls but it feeds thouſands, yet there is not a ſhower that falls at which thouſands do not murmur. Shall we be ſo unjuſt?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Paulina! I think thou art—ſomething divine!—Give me my palette, Nannette—Though fate girn at us, we can be merry; ay, and ſing, and— (Sits down to painting) Courage! Courage! We have hearts that can endure.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And hands that can labour.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Indignant) I had forgotten. We are plebeians.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dee vomans vill not no more truſt.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Starting up) There's no ſupporting it!—Dunned by a ſmall ware pedlar in penny loaves! Refuſed credit for a few ſhillings! The ſon of Craig Campbell!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Soothing) A few ſhillings to this poor woman may be ruin.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p:
Very true— (Snatching up his bruſh) Tell
her, I will paint her a picture ſhall make the fortune of her whole family! Tell her, I have the art to transform two yards ſquare of canvas to the worth of a province.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mon dieu! I'll not a tell ſuch lie.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Courage, Paulina.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Fear nothing, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Vhen I am yong, in Straſbourg, me huſband vas paint; but he vas no fool, he vas no paint canevas, he vas paint houſe, door, und ſign poſt.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Sign poſts?—I?—Inſolent idea! Woman! My name is Craig Campbell.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You ſay you not tell your name, more as Craig; und you bawl ſo loud mit all dee vorld to hear.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: When I am angry I care not who hears—Well, be it Craig: I would not have the name of Campbell diſhonoured. (Paints) There's a tint! Look, Paulina. There's an effect! Ha, ha, ha! Sign poſts!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dee landlady ſhwear, und tear, und play dee diable for dee rent.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Working with great eagerneſs) She ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Comment?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: She ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You leave Italy, you come back mit your own country, you ave dee grand relationſhip, und—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Nannette!—Don't make me mad. Talk of any thing but my grand relations. I am a man, an independent, honeſt, honourable man; and have forſworn grandeur. It once ſpurned at me—And why? Becauſe I was poor—I now ſpurn at it!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Fie, Nannette. Forget it, dear ſir.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: At a word. 'Tis gone. But we'll be free, Paulina, ſhall we not?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh, yes.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Why then, ſmile world or frown, we can live, can forgive thy injuſtice, and rejoice at thy proſperity.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh, my noble father!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ay, girl, as the nobleſt. They may clothe me in rags, feed me on offals, load me with fetters; but there is that here, which contemns their injuſtice, and defies their perſecution.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Allons! Va! It is paſt a mit twelve o'clock.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: True. The lord to whom I ſent a pair of pictures has appointed to ſee me. I muſt go. Yet why? I ſhall gain no admittance. Not at home, is the everlaſting anſwer. The inſolent porter will ſcarcely open the gate wide enough for my hand to enter. But I am poor, and muſt wait, and come again, and again, and take affronts patiently. So it is. The lord within, ſits in ſtate, reveling, banqueting, and tantalizing the palled appetite; while the wretch without, repulſed, inſulted, and refuſed his due, is perhaps periſhing with hunger!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Eh bien; he has a not been here yet.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Who? My Seymour; my Charles?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais, oui.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Alas, no—For ſeven long inexplicable days he has been abſent!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Quoi donc? You ſo impatience!—He promiſe und ſay he vas vait for his riche oncle; und he vas tell his amour, und he vas get his conſent, & donc tout de ſuite, he vas marry you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Yes, he promiſed—And he will keep his promiſe. Seymour will keep his promiſe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Eh bien, donc! He come ſo ſoon as ven his oncle is mit return.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Very true—Then why am I reſtleſs? Why do I pine? Do I not know my Seymour? His heart and ſoul are faith and truth! Perjured? Seymour? Oh! no, no, no, no, no! No power can make him violate vows ſo ſacred, oaths ſo ſolemn! No; that is impoſſible!—Then why theſe forebodings? It is becauſe I have been deceitful! Silent to a father, who is himſelf all ſincerity, and whoſe abundant heart aches with affection for me!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oui! He vas die mit grand coeur to make his ſhile happy!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why then, Nannette, have you indulged me in this guilty deluſion?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dere now! Voyez vous! I am old fool! You make a lofe, I make a pity you, und dat is all my tank! Dee yong gentleman ſee you in dee ſtreet, he fall in lofe mit you, he make pretend to take leſſon mit your fader, und vat I do? I vatch for you, I keep your ſecret, I carry your letter, und, now, me voila bien payé!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Nay, Nannette.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Your fader ſhould be more ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And becauſe he has not ſuſpected, becauſe he has generouſly confided in me, I have been mean and treacherous! Well may I forebode ſome dreadful puniſhment!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am hear news, ſince I am go mitout.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: News! What news?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Tres mauvais.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Bad! Does it relate to Seymour?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais, oui.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What is it? Tell me inſtantly!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You know I ave country voman, dat live mit dee great Lady Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dee herr Seymour, come und make viſit mit her very ſouvent.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Viſit!—Who? Lady Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: She tell a me ſo. Und ſhe ſay, Lady Fancourt make a dee lofe mit him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: With my Seymour?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Und ſhe ſay too dat dey vill make a de marriage bien tot.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Marry?—Seymour and Lady Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ah, oui!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (In agony) Impoſſible! Impoſſible! Perjury and Seymour? Perjury ſo deep, ſo ſeductive, ſo deteſtable! No, it cannot be!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Je l'eſpere bien.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I'll write to him this inſtant! I'll write in tears; or if they are too weak to move him, in blood! Let him read, and if he have the power, if he have the heart, let him ſuffer me longer to remain in this excruciating torment! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV. The Dreſſing-room of Lady FANCOURT—
div.stage: Lady FANCOURT at her toilette: JULETTE waiting.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Uneaſy and agitated) This pompoon is frightful—Take it away—Mr. Seymour has not been here?

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: No, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: How pale and ſpotted I am!

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: Shall I give you the carmine, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: No—Yes—I hate carmine! I look like a witch!—Are you ſure Mr. Seymour has not called?

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: Quite ſure, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: You are very alert, and confident.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: My lady?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Softening) Take that robe, Julette, I wore yeſterday: it is your own.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: You are the kindeſt of ladies!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: May be the blundering porter has denied me to him?

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—Whom?—Mr. Seymour.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: I cautioned him myſelf, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Cautioned?—Cautioned?—Did you mention my name?

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: I told him it was your ladyſhip's own order.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: And who authorized you to be ſo forward?

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: You yourſelf, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Did I?—Julette (Taking her hand) I fear I treat you unkindly. (Quitting her) I begin to deſpiſe myſelf—Three days and not one call; not one enquiry!—I am at home to nobody but Mr. Seymour.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: Not to Mr. Muſcadel?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I tell you, no.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: (Aſide) Mercy! Here's change! (Going)

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Stay— (Aſide) What am I doing?—Lightly encourage, and lightly diſcard; is that my character? Is he altered, or am I? I thought I loved him—Oh no; 'twas a vain fancy. I have ſince been taught that love, wiſhing, reſtleſs, burning love, is only to be kindled by neglect—Perhaps, by ſcorn—Scorned?— (To Julette) Admit Mr. Muſcadel, and deny me to Mr. Seymour.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: My lady!—Yes, my lady. (Going in a hurry)

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Come back—You are in great haſte.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: Mr. Muſcadel is a pleaſant good natured gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Who gave you leave to ſpeaks?

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: My lady?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p:
(Softening) Julette— (Aſide) Am I
lunatic?—Leave me, my good girl—I'll raiſe your wages.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: Dear—

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Go. I can't talk— [Exit Julette] (Knocking at the ſtreet door) Julette!

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: (Without) My lady!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Deny me to Mr. Muſcadel.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: Yes, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Yet why? What has he done? What will the world ſay?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Without) I tell you I know to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: (Without) Nay but indeed, ſir! Pray, ſir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You miſtook your orders.

sp.speaker: Julette.
sp.p: No indeed, ſir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I knew you were at home—Good morrow to your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Theſe liberties, ſir—I did not chooſe to be at home.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: To any body but me: that was kind. (Aſide) This is ſtrange!—There was more in that tale of Seymour than I imagined.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I know not how, ſir, I have ſubjected myſelf to ſuch freedoms.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: By your amiable and poliſhed manners: by being too well bred to take offence— (Aſide) She wants to quarrel, but I'm determined to keep my temper. Ay, ay! This is Seymour!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Mr. Muſcadel, if, by any thoughtleſs conduct, I have given you cauſe to imagine more than was meant, I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p:
Oh no—The Graces have been attiring you!—I never imagine. My imagination is as dull
as candlemas-day, in a country-hall, and a viſit from the vicar.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I am not diſpoſed to trifle. You may accuſe me of caprice; and I own I am not certain the accuſation would be falſe.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Impoſſible! I cannot accuſe; I can only adore. (Aſide) It is as I ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Will you underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You have an infinitude of charms, and infinitude is above my comprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I am determined—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: To liſten to my wild flights: you have had the ſame complaiſance a thouſand times. Angelic ſweetneſs!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Once more—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Aurora on a May-morning never looked ſo lovely!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to attempt—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: To reſiſt ſuch divinity! Vain indeed!—But I have ſomething to tell you—I have juſt made a call in the ſquare.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: The ſquare?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh, ho!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Which ſquare?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Cavendiſh— (Aſide) I have touched the maſter key at laſt.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Well, but—? To tell me?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Hem!—Yes—I ſaw Sir Gregory, and Lady Louiſa—

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Tedious!—Was that all? Nobody elſe?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide and glancing) Hem!—Oh! I recollect—True—Mr. Seymour—He is juſt returned.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Eagerly) Has he been out of town?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Who? Mr. Seymour?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Hem!—Oh dear, no: Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Tormenting!—Did he—aſk after me?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: With the greateſt reſpect. You are his chief favourite.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I mean Sir Gregory's.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Is this inſult?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Mr. Seymour, too, mentioned your name: a civil enquiry.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Am I betraying myſelf? Is he making me his amuſement?—Mr. Muſcadel—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nay, you have not heard my ſtory. It will ſurpriſe you.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: What ſtory?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: A love one. Mr. Seymour—

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Well!—Why don't you go on?—Is Mr. Seymour in love?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Deeply! Deſpondingly!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Can that be the reaſon?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Perhaps you have heard with whom?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I—Not with any certainty.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Never was poor youth ſo ſmitten!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: And deſpairs of ſucceſs?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: No ray of hope.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: But why? Is ſhe a queen?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: The very queen herſelf of beauty—as I have been told.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Can it be? In love with me?—Then you have not heard who?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh yes—The moſt ridiculous choice!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Poverty, obſcurity, and impending ruin.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: A painter's daughter! Sir Gregory will certainly diſinherit him.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) This then is the ſecret cauſe!—Yet— (To Muſcadel) Are you not indulging your invention?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Emphatically) Matter of fact, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: From whom do you get your intelligence?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: A Mrs. Wilkins; at whoſe houſe the girl and her father live.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: And how ſhould ſuch a woman know?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh! Mrs. Wilkins is a very well informed lady. But you may eaſily ſatisfy yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: 'Tis only in Duke-ſtreet: call in and view the pictures: (Lady Fancourt rings) or ſit for your portrait. There needs no ceremony.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (To Footman) Order my carriage.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Soothing) Shall I attend you?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You ſeem—moved.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I generally am what I ſeem.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: A common caſe this: the feelings ſtrong, the failings great.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Sir! Was that to me?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Upon my—

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I wiſh no apologies—When you came in I would have explained; you would not hear—I wiſh to avoid—that is—Excuſe me, but—In ſhort—Pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſſuming a manly and impaſſioned tone) Lady Fancourt, you have examined me too ſuperficially: you have noticed only the ſhell; the habits and manners which wild cuſtom and tame convenience may have taught. Be juſt, and look a little deeper. You think I have no heart: you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: 'Tis you that miſtake: I knew more of your heart than of my own. [Knocking heard.]

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Here is company, and we muſt not now have either hearts or feelings. We muſt put on the maſk, keep our temper, and be as placid as Mandarins on a mantle-piece, to ſhew our breeding.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: You may: I cannot—Nobody will be admitted.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nobody?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: But—Mr. Seymour.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Lady Fancourt!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I tell you the plain truth. If he come—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I muſt go?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I ſhall take it as a favour.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) No, even this ſhall not throw me off my guard. In love, as in war, the cool combatant has the beſt chance of victory.

div.head: SCENE VI. Enter Footman and SEYMOUR.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Mr. Seymour! Is it you? I thought you had been gone to the Indies, or the Antipodes, or ſome ſtrange place.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Hem!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip is late at your toilette today.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Am I? It is ſo difficult to pleaſe one's ſelf.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: In order to pleaſe us.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip needs no factitious ornament, no aid from the toilette to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Take care, Mr. Seymour: you are a man of principle, with you ſincerity is a virtue.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: It is ſurely, madam, no offence to ſincerity to ſay that beauty, like truth, is the moſt ſplendid when leaſt encumbered.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Tolerably well that, but a little too ſentimental.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Will he not go?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You do well, Seymour, to come here for leſſons. See with what faſhionable originality Lady Fancourt and I expreſs, I mean conceal, our mutual affection.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: 'Tis true I have ſacrificed, as I ought, fifty of the fineſt women in England to her ladyſhip's ſuperior charms.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I thought, Mr. Muſcadel, what had juſt paſſed would have relieved me from ſuch inſulting freedoms.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nay, all the world knows I am your adorer; and what harm in telling that which all the world knows? Charles here I dare ſay is your adorer too.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Do you, Mr. Muſcadel, or do you not, remember what has been ſaid?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Perfectly, my lady. Courage, Charles! I am ſorry I am obliged to leave you. You will be very dull when I am gone. Talk, man, talk! Don't ſtand ſtudying half an hour for a civil thing; looking as ſtupid as a poet in ſearch of a ſimile, and as inanimate as a wooden lion at the head of a Dutch ſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Intolerable.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: But Ha, ha, ha! Love is your religion, you are a quaker by ſect, and your ſilence is a ſign of your devotion. You will find him very entertaining, Lady Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: The entertainment, ſir, which conſiſts in gratifying ſpleen at the expence of feeling, is not very enviable.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p:
Spleen? Oh, no; you miſtake. Ha, ha, ha! I never knew what ſpleen, envy, or jealouſy
were in my life. Never—But I am ſorry to puniſh you both, by leaving you together. You will ſoon miſs me! Charles, don't begin to yawn too ſoon. And let me tell you a ſecret, before I go. Woman, you know, is a riddle: the ſolution to which is, you muſt either uſe her very ill, or be treated worſe by her than a ſtraggling hound by a whipper-in. La, la, la, la. Good-morrow to your ladyſhip. Don't think I am ſplenetic. Ha, ha, ha! I am not jealous, Charles. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Mr. Muſcadel beneath the maſk of levity conceals an excellent underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Do you think ſo? I have ſometimes been of that opinion, ſometimes not.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: As a proof, he has a real reſpect and admiration for your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: For me, or for my rank, wealth, and powerful connexions?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: If I can judge, his paſſion is ſincere and ardent.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it—The caprices of love, Mr. Seymour, are often cruel.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: And often fatal. Yet I begin to ſuſpect they are the mere creatures of our own diſordered imaginations.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) There is hope in that thought—Why true. How then can we anſwer it to our relations, or the world, if, ſeduced by ſome fancied beauties of perſon, perhaps by the mere accident of complexion, which a froſty air gives and a gloomy day deſtroys, looking no deeper, we turn from proſperity and wilfully embrace ruin; in which we not only involve ourſelves but all who are neareſt and deareſt to the heart?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: (Diſturbed) 'Tis cowardice! Guilt!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Preceded by perturbation, followed by remorſe; beginning in folly, ending in deſpair.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: (In a deep reverie) The picture is falſe! Not thy complexion, Paulina! No; 'tis thy emanating divine mind!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Mr. Seymour.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Madam—I have a weakneſs—It hourly hurries me into abſurdity.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) And what have I?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I am unfit company—

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Nay, one moment—Your uncle has told me you have thoughts of marriage. 'Tis a ſerious act. What is its end? Your birth is noble, your talents are great, your expectations cannot be too high. The happineſs of your family is at ſtake: the eye of the world is fixed upon you. Love, you own, is but the creature of fancy—You would not marry—a painter's daughter?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Look forward to the honours that are poſſible.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I deſpiſe them.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Well then, to the good you may effect; the happineſs you may diffuſe.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Ay, that is a weighty thought!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: A claim, which mankind has upon you. Diſgrace your family, deſtroy your peace, and deſert your duty? It muſt not be!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: The motives indeed are powerful.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Think me intereſted, and perhaps • am; I ſcorn hypocriſy; but, if I ſpeak truth, conſider and reſolve. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p:
Why ſo!—The warfare thickens and the battle rages!—She has a noble mind!—Her arguments are potent!—Yet ſhe knows not all. Oh! Paulina! Muſt a ſiſter, or muſt thou, be ſacrificed? Something muſt be done. Yet every hour increaſes
ſtupefaction! My mind confuſed, my powers confounded, I deſpiſe my own imbecility yet cannot ſhake it off! Like hag-ridden ſleep, gaſping for breath, and heaving for motion, I am chained down in agonizing impotence! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. The Houſe of Sir GREGORY OLDWORT.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (IN a half whiſper and ſignificantly) Mrs. Vilkins is below, Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſſuming anger) Who?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (With continued ſignificance) Mrs. Vilkins.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What do you mean? What does ſhe want? Who is Mrs. Wilkins?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Oh! Boh! Your honour knows Mrs. Vilkins wery vell. The old lodging houſe lady; vhere the pretty—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What is that you ſay, fellow? I know! I—!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Vhere your honour uſed to wiſit ſo often, laſt vinter.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why, man, do you mean to inſinuate—?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Lord, no, your honour! I means to ſinniate nothing, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: How often muſt I warn you, ſirrah, that theſe freedoms of yours are intolerable?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Nay your honour wery vell knows I am cloſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: How dare you, fellow, reptile, ſlave, comment on my actions? "Mine? Your liege lord, vaſſal?"

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I commit your actions? Lord, your honour, I am not a tenth part ſo vicked a ſinner! But I likes you ſhould call me names, for then you doesn't forget huſh money.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I'll diſmiſs you inſtantly—

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: So you have ſaid a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: For your infernal impudence.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: No; 'tis for that you keeps me. I ſhouldn't ſuit your honour if I hadn't a bit o'braſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Begone! Quit my preſence.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Your honour forgets! Mrs. Vilkins is below!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: "Was ever a man of my family, my dignity, thus inſulted by his knave, his ſlave, his ſerf, his villain!" What is it that your Mrs. Wilkins wants with me?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Vhy, ſhe ſays, hearing as how your honour is juſt returned to town, (Looking round) ſhe has a lodger.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What, a a a young—? Hem! (Reſuming his dignity) What is that to me, fellow?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: A fine bit o' bloom!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why, ſirrah—!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Nay! I doesn't mean to ſinniate nothing!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Begone, ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Oh! Vell!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Come back, do you hear?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (Laughing) Your honour?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: How dare you, fellow—!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Your honour?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Let that woman in?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (Going) Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: To turn her out.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg▪
sp.p: Turn—!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I'll ſhew her the ſhort vay.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Come back, hound! How dare you—?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Muſt I ſend her out?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why, ſlave—!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Or ſend her up?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Reptile!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Lord, Sir Gregory, there's no pleaſing you. But I knows wery vell vhat your honour vould be at, ſo I'll ſend her up. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: The manners of this malicious age are inſufferable! If one of our ancient Barons thought proper to have his concubine, what vaſſal refuſed his daughter? Who durſt breathe diſapprobation? He had a certain cure for calumny; a gallows, on his own domains; himſelf the judge. But now his very Menials ſit in judgment on his character; and ſip it up in tea, coffee, limmonade, and the reſt of their contemptible ſmall tipple.

div.head: SCENE II. Enter Mrs. WILKINS and JAMES.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: How comes it, Mrs. Wilkins, that—?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Not a ſoul ſaw me come up, Sir Gregory. (Sir Gregory ſtops to conſider at each ſuggeſtion of Mrs. Wilkins, then reverts to his dignity)

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: A man of my dignity!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (Pointing to her bonnet) My curtain over my face—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: The family of Oldwort!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I am not known in this neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Who ſhall dare—?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: There was no creature in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: My character, madam, muſt be reſpected!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Not a ſervant in the houſe has ſet eyes on me, except James.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Expoſed to the ſcandal of of—! Are you ſure my niece, Lady Louiſa, did not ſee you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Certain, Sir Gregory!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (With his uſual ſigns) She's gone out, your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why how now, caitiff! How dare you ſtand liſtening—? Begone!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I'll keep vatch, your honour!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: The wicked tongues of this wicked world—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: The ſweeteſt creature!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Hey! What?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I knew, Sir Gregory—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What did you know? Mrs. Wilkins, you give yourſelf very ſtrange liberties!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: An angel!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Hey! Who? What, what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Eyes never beheld her equal!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Enchanting!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: So very beautiful?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: In the full bloom of youth!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Auburn hair?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Blue eyes!

sp.speaker: "Sir Greg.
sp.p: Slender waiſt?

sp.speaker: "Mrs. W.
sp.p: Ivory teeth!

sp.speaker: "Sir Greg.
sp.p: Pouting lips?

sp.speaker: "Mrs. W.
sp.p: Snow white neck!"

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Is ſhe at home?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And alone, at this very moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: At this moment. (Sir Gregory rings) She has a father, and an old gouvernante.

div.head: SCENE III. Enter JAMES with a large hat and roquelaure.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Here is your honour's ſlouched hat and cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why, hind! This fellow's familiar inſolence would drive a man mad!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: You may ſlip out, Sir Gregory, in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Fungus!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (Looking through the door) All is ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Woman!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: There is a hackney coach vaiting round the corner. (A loud rap is heard at the door)

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Zounds! Here's ſomebody coming! (Making ſigns to James) Quick! Quick!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (Stealing off) Never fear, your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (To Mrs. Wilkins) Up with your cloak; down with your curtain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (Curtſying) I humbly thank your honour. Your honour is a good gentleman, a kind gentleman, and a father to the friendleſs!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Pompouſly) Go, go; good woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs your honour! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: So, ſir! Did not I lay my commands on you to viſit Lady Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I have obeyed your commands, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Oh, you have? It is your wiſeſt courſe.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: So ſay prudence and pride; but principle and inclination pull the contrary way.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What do you mean by inclination, ſir? How dare you ſuppoſe you have inclinations?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Who has not?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ah! So that, like a ſhip at anchor, you are always in motion, without ever making any way!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Exactly ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Inclination, indeed! Get an eſtate; get rank; get honour. Your ſiſter, too, has her inclinations: but let her beware!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (Aſide to Sir Gregory) The coach is vaiting. Muſt I ſend it avay?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide but angrily) Begone, mungrel!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Hah! That means, no—I'll take care, your honour. The hat and cloak is ready in the hall. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Sternly) Look to it, ſir! I am reſolved. Lady Fancourt is of one of our firſt families, has a fine eſtate, is in high favour at court. To refuſe ſuch a match were idiotiſm, or lunacy. Inclination? My age, ſtation, and character, demand reſpect: I am your natural guardian, counſellor, and guide; make me your mirror; curb your paſſions; follow good example, good advice, good morals. Keep your character clear, your conduct chaſte, your conſcience pure, and obey your betters. Mark me, ſir; I am reſolved! Inclinations indeed?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: (Peeping in at the door, and aſide) All is ready!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide) Scoundrel! Hem! (Aloud) Inclinations indeed!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Why, ay. Riches, rank, and power, bought at the expence of perturbation, perjury, and—murder!—I know her heart: ſhe could not, would not, ſurvive my treachery!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Well, Charles; what ſtill in the mournfuls?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I am the moſt irreſolute, moſt childiſh, moſt miſerable of men.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ah; you have been to Paulina?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Would I had! I ſhould then at leaſt be relieved from ſuſpence: ſhould be hers everlaſtingly, or everlaſtingly ſeparated from her. No ſtate of mind can be more degrading, than that in which I remain.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: But you have been ſomewhere?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Yes: to viſit Lady Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Seym
sp.p: She has heard of Paulina.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Do not think me vain—ſhe is jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Then Sir Gregory will be told! What will become of us?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Your huſband is my friend; I love his amiable qualities; but they are delicate, not daring: they would ſhrink and wither, at the touch of miſfortune.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I, and I only, ſeem to have the power to preſerve a ſiſter, a friend, and a brother. But the means? Oh, did you know Paulina! Her mind, vaſt and luminous! Extinguiſhed? Trodden out, by me? Horrible thought!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: If it be ſo ſtrong, there is no fear.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: It has its weakneſs: I have mine. Read that letter.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Paulina: the deceived, afflicted, injured, yet ever faithful Paulina! Read.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Reads) "This is the eighth day that my Seymour, my beloved, has been abſent! Where is he? Where is my bridegroom, my huſband; for ſo, in the preſence of heaven and all the heavenly hoſt, he is? Am I forgotten? They tell me of a lady! Where art thou, Seymour? Where is the beloved of my ſoul? Has he forſaken me? Oh, no! Deteſted be the unjuſt the ungenerous thought! Come, in pity come, leſt phrenzy ſuddenly ſeize on thy Paulina!"—Poor dear girl!—What can be done?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Something dreadful! Something that ſhall teach youth the horrid torments attendant on deceit; that ſhall make me a fearful example of blind, raſh, unequal love!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Charles! Collect your thoughts. Terror and diſtraction may increaſe, but cannot cure, evil.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: And muſt I then live and die a perjured wretch?—A monſter?—Oh the villany of raſhneſs! Did you know how I laboured, intreated, threatened, wept, ſwore! Solemn oaths, wild phrenzies, deſperate threats, no horror had been left unacted had ſhe perſevered in rejecting me! What then had ſhe been faithleſs, perjured as I am? Oh! Madneſs!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Brother! Charles! [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Fine airs, indeed! But I'll ſend you to a ſafe place.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Aſide) Carogne!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Run in every body's debt, pay no rent, and ſtand upon your punctilios, truly!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais, madame—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: An old gentleman, a modeſt gentleman, a kind gentleman, ay and a baronet!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: No leſs a perſon than Sir Gregory Oldwort!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Struck with the name) Qui? Vat you ſay? Dee Chevalier Oldvort?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Shivalyay indeed? I ſay, to Sir Gregory Oldwort!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ah, dieu! Vhy you not tell ſo much ſoon before?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh, ho!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Und dee Chevalier Oldvort know my maitreſſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: How ſhould he know her? She would not ſo much as ſhew her face!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais, ſhe not know it vas dee Chevalier, autrement—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: In plain Engliſh, will ſhe admit his viſits, or will ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais mon dieu! Dee Chevalier not make a lofe mit my maitreſſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: What can I tell? Why not? May be no; may be yes. That's their affair. I have nothing to do with people's private concerns.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
Ah, j'entens! I ſpeak mit Paulina, und,
vhen dee Chevalier Oldvort is return, you tell a me; et nous verrons.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Well, well. But this matter muſt be managed cautiouſly. The old gentleman muſt not be ſeen. Nobody muſt come in, while he is here. You underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oui, oui. Let a me do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: You muſt not ſeem to know who he is.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais, pour quoi? Vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Anan? I tell you, he would not be known for the world. So mind what I ſay, be cautious and compliant; or, remember—! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Bon dieu! Dee Chevalier Oldvort! Vat ſhall I vill do?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ah! Nannette!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Eh bien?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I am in high ſpirits! I have had an interview with his lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Bon.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: He is well bred; underſtands character; talked to me on terms of equality; never once reminded me that he was a peer, and I—? A painter!—He is a man of ſenſe:

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ah, ha! Vat he vas pay you?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Not attending to her) He pleaſed me highly!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He vas pay you mit money?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Curſe money! Mention money to me? No; he treated me like a gentleman:

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Comment!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Inattentive to her) Diſcourſed with eaſe; praiſed my pictures;

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Und vas not give you pay mit money?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Pointed out their beauties, frankly told me their defects—

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Patience! He not pay you mit money?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Peace! Woman. Damn money! Do you forget who I am? You are determined to put me in an ill humour.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: J'enrage! Here is dee vilaine landlady ſhe turn us all out, our head mit dee door.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ha! More dunning? More? Well, well!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: She put us mit dee priſon, und ſhe make us all ſtarve und die mit hunger.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Me; not you. I defy her malice.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Vat you ſay?—Not me?—You go to priſon, you ſtrave mit hunger, und I not go to priſon, I not ſtarve mit hunger, too?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Woman, I have already too many obligations to you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais c'eſt trop! I am live mit you twenty year; I am nurſe your ſhile; I am die mit your vife, ma pauvre maitreſſe; I am eat mit you, drink mit you, laugh mit you, cry mit you, and I am not go to priſon mit you? I am not die mit hunger mit you? Barbare!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Oh this ſtubborn heart!—Good affectionate creature (Taking her hand) Yes, Nannette, if ſo it muſt be we'll rot, ſtarve, and die together!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Eagerly kiſſing his hand) Mon bon maitre! Mon cher ami! You alvays ave dee heart—Tenez—So big! Comme ça— (Making a circle ever her whole boſom) Und I ave dee heart ſo big, too.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p:
So thou haſt, Nannette. I have tried it, and hope yet to ſee it rewarded—But this money! This vile contaminating traffic—I muſt ſubmit.
I'm to be paid this afternoon. The ſteward was out and I, tradeſman like, muſt call again.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ha! Dat is mit vhat dee Milors pay dere debt: call again! Call again? Ha! I don't a lofe call again. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VIII. Changes to the Houſe of Sir GREGORY OLDWORT.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Oh, brother!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: All is over! I'm betrayed!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Sir Gregory—Mr. Compton directs my letters under cover to his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Sir Gregory's ſuſpicions have induced him to continue his viſits to her: ſhe had juſt received a letter for me, had ſtript off the cover and laid it for a moment on her dreſſing table: Sir Gregory abruptly came in, ſaw the direction, "to Lady Louiſa Compton," ſnatched it up, and deaf to the intreaties of poor Miſs Compton refuſed to return it, determined he ſaid to deliver it himſelf.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: How do you know all this?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Miſs Compton's woman came running terrified and out of breath to tell me.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: What can be done?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I am ruined! Mr. Compton is ruined!

div.head: SCENE IX. Enter Sir GREGORY (With Letter)

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: So, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (In great confuſion) Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Compton is your name?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My dear uncle—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Sternly) Silence, ſir!—Will you pleaſe to read me this letter; or muſt I be under the neceſſity of breaking the ſeal?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: If I might hope for your forgiveneſs, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Will you read me the letter?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Your anger, ſir, overpowers my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Silence, once more!—Your name is Compton?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Falling on her knee) It is, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Prepare to leave this houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: For the love of pity—!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Prepare to leave this houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I am fatherleſs, I am fortuneleſs, I am in your power: you are my uncle; do with me what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Left in indigence by a diſſipated father, abandoned by the ſpendthrift peer your brother, I foſtered, I protected you; I watched to preſerve the family dignity from taint; my charity would have reſcued the name of Oldwort from degradation.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: (Aſide) Admirable charity!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: But the object for which I laboured is loſt, and I renounce you! I ſhake you off! You are an alien to my blood, and your puniſhment will be my daily prayer.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Conſider, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Ay and you, ſir, if you utter another word; you too, with your inclinations! Nay, if an hour hence I find you here, madam, the next hour ſhall rid me of you both!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p:
(Picking it up) Be comforted, Louiſa. There is yet one deſperate courſe to take. I am
now your only protector: it is fit I ſhould devote myſelf. Were it only myſelf—? 'Tis madneſs, and miſery! But it muſt be done.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Not for me! You ſhall not be miſerable for me!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Every duty calls upon me; and, in addition to them all, the ſalvation of a ſiſter! It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: What will become of me? Where muſt I go?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: With me to Lady Fancourt. I will put you under her protection.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And ſacrifice yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Duty, reaſon, fraternal affection, all demand it. Come; there is no time to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: This muſt not be!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: We muſt not argue, muſt not think; that were diſtraction: my hour at length is come, and now act I muſt. Oh, Paulina! I'll ſee her once more, take one laſt eternal adieu, then, if my heart ſtrings hold but this, crack them who can!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: NOT at home, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: She will ſoon be back, my lady. I think I hear her voice below, now.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Why am I here? Rivaled by an obſcure unprotected indigent creature? I? Flattered and purſued as I have been, for my beauty rank and riches, and rivaled? Thus rivaled too? Dreading, envying, nay half hating a low born girl, whom I have never ſeen? Is it real? Can I thus ſtoop and forget my better reaſon and my proud fortunes? What miracle is ſhe; and what poor pitiable thing am I?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Stands admiring) Why yes! She is beautiful! Her countenance beams intelligence and ſoul!—Pray leave us. [Exit Mrs. Wilkins.] Your name is Paulina?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: It is, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) What ſweetneſs of voice!—I am come to talk to you. Take courage: ſpeak your ſentiments freely.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry, madam, to need the caution. Being conſcious of no ill, I know not why or what I ought to fear.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Indeed! So firm?—Superior wealth rank and power uſually inſpire ſuch fears.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Uſually, but unworthily. 'Tis the degradation of mind to fear any thing, but guilt.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) Wonderful!—I had heard of your beauty, and am ſurpriſed at your underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: They are both of them accidents. If I poſſeſs them, I can but ill explain how, or why.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) There is witchery about her!—Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Do you know—Mr. Seymour?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Does your firmneſs leave you?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No: but the queſtion is abrupt.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Does it offend?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: There is ſomething in you, madam, which aſſures me it is not your cuſtom to intend offence; and I will not think you intend it now.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) This is ſtrange! Sentiments ſo juſt, ſo uncommon, and in a painter's daughter? 'Tis amazing!—I came to reaſon with you, to warn you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Againſt what?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Miſtake, miſery, crime: the deſertion of duty, the contempt of the world, and the hatred of him whom your allurements have inveigled.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Suppreſſing paſſion) Madam, I will again ſuppoſe you do not intend to wound; I will therefore reſolve not to feel—But you do me injuſtice—I am young, have neither the wealth, rank, nor power you ſeem to revere; yet I am no inveigler.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Your ſpirit is high!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I mean it to be no more than juſt; if I exceed, I am ſorry.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) She is an extraordinary creature!—Think on the conſequences—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: A union ſo unequal!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I have thought, and can diſcover no true inequality, but between virtue and vice.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Thus we palliate our errors. Selfiſhneſs is the lurking motive. So that our own petty concerns do but proſper, we care not though the world go to wrcck!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p:
Convince me of any wrong I ſhall do to Seymour or to juſtice, and I will ſuffer martyrdom rather than commit it. For the mere forms and
rules of an arrogant and intereſted world I have but little reſpect.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Aſide) She aims to tower above me! Am I unjuſt? Is it not pride in her? Is it not preſumption? In ſome gifts perhaps my equal, in others ſurely ſhe is my inferior. And ſhall I cede the high claims of love; the dear affections of the heart? But their paſſion is mutual. Be it ſo: what is it but mutual folly? My views are rational, my motives dignified, and merit ſucceſs. Her's are romantic, fatal to order and the peace of families, and muſt be ſhall be fruſtrated.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip's carriage is come back, as you ordered.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Very well—I have given you good advice, reflect on what I have ſaid. You have received great gifts: act as becomes you, and increaſe the admiration you have raiſed. But, beware! Indulge no fond folly. Attempt not to graſp the ſtars! Seymour and his alliances are above you. Shun raſhneſs, follow good counſel, and dread involving yourſelf and him you pretend to love in wretchedneſs. Dare not to ſet vice ſo dangerous an example! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Wiſhing to be heard) Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Pray take care, your ladyſhip!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (To Paulina) 'Tis the great Lady Fancourt! Huſh! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p:
Lady Fancourt? Heavens! What do theſe warnings, theſe threats portend? I cannot be deceived? Theſe haughty claims theſe arrogant diſtinctions of wealth and birth are not, cannot be juſt! But ſhe declares her views on Seymour! Where is
he? Why is he ſtill abſent? My letter unanſwered! What are his thoughts? What are his feelings? What are his deſigns? Oh!— (Falls in a chair covering her face with her hands.)

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Suddenly ſtarting up and running to her) Nannette! Haſt thou ſeen him? Has he read my letter? Will he come?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Par hazard, I ave ſee him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Haſt thou?—And the letter?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He has not anſwer mit your letter.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Wildly) No anſwer?—No anſwer?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mais quelle impatience! He is not write mit anſwer; but he is vill be here, now by and by.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Will he? Will he?—Oh, yes! Do I not know my Seymour? How ſhall I expiate the frequent ſuſpicions of his faith, of which I have lately been guilty?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Chut! Taiſez vous! Your fader is come.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Haſt thou not thought me long, Paulina?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Here, Nannette; take this tradeſman's dirt: it fouls my fingers.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Pay it away; rid me of it! I feel my ſoul groveling at the touch.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ciel! Dee money make pay mit dee Milor! Eh! I am very great big mit joy! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Wages, counted out by a menial, for work done and delivered for his maſter. Ah!—

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Good-morrow, my worthy friends. (Paulina diſcovers great joy)

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: My pupil? I am glad to ſee you!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Have you been walking?
