sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Buſineſs. Following my trade. Doing as I was bid, and ſigning a receipt in full, with a bow a cringe and a humbly thank you, ſir! I hope for your future cuſtom! No ſhopkeeper in England will ſerve you better!—I have learned the whole trick of it.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: If you think labour an indignity, you are wrong.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: What, ſo much per day?—Well!—No matter. But how has it happened that you, the friend of my art, have abſented yourſelf for a whole week?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: (Embarraſſed) The expectation—My uncle was out of town.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Is he returned?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I applaud your dutiful attention—Your marriage then will ſoon take place? (Paulina extremely alarmed)

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Confuſed) What marriage? Who tells you—?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Oh! The woman below; a thouſand idle goſſips buſy themſelves in ſpreading reports that relate to perſons of high life (Paulina's agitation increaſes) The union is ſpoken of with applauſe.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: (Watching Paulina in the back ground) What union, ſir?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: With Lady Fancourt.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: But, ſir—I aſſure you—It is not—That is, I have never propoſed ſuch a marriage to her ladyſhip. (Paulina relieved)

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Nay, if you could not be happy, far be it from me to wiſh for ſuch an event.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Then happy I nevér could be (Joy of Paulina—Pauſe) But what ſubjects are you employed on at preſent?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Various. I have a picture I wiſh to ſhew you. It ſtill wants a few touches. I have left it in the parlour. Will you have the goodneſs to wait a moment? [Exit.

div.head: SCENE VII. PAULINA runs to SEYMOUR.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My Seymour! (Looking ſtedfaſtly for a moment, then affectionately ſnatching his hand) My Seymour!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My precious Paulina!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Ill: very ill!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Alarmed) Ill?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Wretched!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What doſt thou mean, Seymour? (PAUSE) Why doſt thou look thus deſpondingly on me?—What is there in thy thoughts?—Some dreadful ſecret, ſure!—Speak! Thy ſilence diſtracts me!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Man is born for miſery, guilt, perjury!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (With horror) Seymour?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I have a ſiſter, young, affectionate, and noble minded as thyſelf—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: But deſolate, ruined, devoted to wretchedneſs, unleſs—!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How can—?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Lady Fancourt—!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p:
(With a ſudden cry of anguiſh) Stop!—Forbear! (Falling on her knees and again ſeizing his hand) Thou art mine!— (With wild agony)
Thou art mine!—Caſt thy eyes up to heaven; remember what thou haſt ſworn; remember who hath heard thee! (With frantic fervour)—By that divine, that juſt, that avenging eſſence, whoſe immaculate name thou haſt made thy pledge, I will not ſurvive thy falſhood! (Again with agony) Thou art mine! Thou art mine! (Riſing) Why talk of ſurviving? The maddening brain is murdered by the bare ſuſpicion!

div.head: SCENE VIII. Re-enter CRAIG with the picture; whoſe mind is ſo occupied through the ſcene by his picture, that he does not attend to the agitation of Paulina and Seymour.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Works addreſſed to the imagination are unworthy of praiſe, unleſs they have ſome moral purpoſe. The ſubject I have choſen will meet applauſe from you, ſir, and all whoſe hearts and principles are equally generous and noble—It is the progreſs of ſeduction; beginning in perjury, ending in ſuicide.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Pleaſed) I knew it muſt incite terror!—This is but one of a ſeries of pictures—Here I have imagined—

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Perjury? Here is a portrait of Paulina!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p:
Yes—Perhaps the partiality of a father led me to ſuppoſe the form and countenance of my Paulina miraculouſly adapted to my ſubject—But obſerve—The ſcene is a cave (Pointing) an overhanging rock, a gloomy foreſt in the back ground, ſome broken lights and diſtances on the left, and a deep gulph in front: the heroine here, here the confidante, and here the only guardian they dared to truſt, a faithful maſtiff. Obſerve theſe traits. Behold her, with all her native candor and confidence,
waiting for her expected lover, and imagining all his ſuperior qualities of ſoul; while the godlike picture her fancy forms, of him and his high deſerts, beams in her eyes, and illuminates her countenance!—How ſhall I pourtray the agony of a heart ſo pure and unſuſpecting, when the fearful moment comes? Is it not an intereſting ſubject?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: A ſubject of terror! Horror! Madneſs!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Quitting the picture) Yes, madneſs is one of its principal features—After depicting the dreadful conflict, when ſhe hears the perjured ſeducer is on the eve of marriage with another, after ſhewing her in all the agonies of deſpair, imploring at his feet—perhaps at the feet of his miſtreſs—

div.stage: [Paulina appears to be ſuddenly ſtruck, at this moment, with her father's thought; which ſhe muſt expreſs in action, and run precipitately out of the chamber-door, that leads to the ſtreet. That this may be perceptible, an interruption muſt be put to the Painter's deſcription, by the embarraſſment of Seymour; who, after his exclamation, turns away, unable to ſuſtain the anguiſh of mind he feels. Craig wholly abſorbed by his ſubject]

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Oh! Inſupportable!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ay!—Inſupportable indeed, to a mind like yours; even though but in imagination—What then will you feel, when you ſhall behold a form ſo lovely, ſo angelic, and innocence ſo unſuſpecting, deprived of reaſon; confined in a madhouſe; ſurrounded by miſerable objects; ſtraw, bread, water, and mercileſs keepers; who vainly attempt, with chains and ſcourges, to expel frenzy?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Peace!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Mr. Seymour?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Silence! I ſay—Proceed no farther; if you would not have me act the ſcenes you mean to paint!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Alarmed) I meant—

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Forbear! [Exit: diſtractedly.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: It is ſtrange!—Is it imagination, or—? (A knocking heard) Come in!

div.head: SCENE IX. Enter Lady LOUISA COMPTON.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Is your name Craig, ſir?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: It is, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Is your daughter within?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Looks round) She was here this minute! Nannette!

div.head: SCENE X. Enter NANNETTE: haſtily with hat and cloak over her arm.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Eh! Vat you vant?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Where is Paulina?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Je ne ſçais pas. She vas run out, und I am run after. [Exit: in great haſte.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Nannette!—What is the matter with the woman?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Aſide) I fear all is not right! How ſhall I begin?—My buſineſs here, ſir, excuſe my frankneſs, is, if poſſible, to gain the friendſhip of you and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p:
(Pauſing) Your appearance ſpeaks rank, and the haughtieſt of the hackneyed anſwers of politeneſs would be, "Madam, you do us honour." But I—I once was—No matter. I am a painter: a worker in oils—but no fawner. Misfortune I
fear has made me a little peeviſh; perhaps a little proud, and—Friends?—I doubt we are not fitted to be friends.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Why not?—Mr. Seymour is my brother.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Indeed!—Then you are a happy ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ah!—We all have our ſorrows: I have mine! You are above ceremony—I have a carriage waiting and a commiſſion from Lady Fancourt; an invitation to dine with us.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Me?—Pardon me. I muſt not be exhibited. I know my diſtance, and I will keep it. No footman ſhall ſneer over my ſhoulder. No lady ſhall act civility to keep me from ſinking in her preſence. No lord ſhall put his half-dozen inſipid interrogatories, to convince me he has not quite forgotten I am of the ſpeaking ſpecies—A little ſore, here—I have been ſcourged—I once ſaw ſunſhine, afar off—Clouds! Clouds!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: You love your art?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: With a burning zeal!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Then why deſpiſe to practice it?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: What! Genius labouring for ſcraps, and even they denied him? Miſery his attendant; priſons in proſpect; penury goading, famine gazing at him!—Beſide—my name is—Pſhaw! I'm a fool.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Aſide) I muſt ſpeak—Your daughter—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Ay! There is the laſh—Yet, why? Ineſtimable girl! My heart is full of her image!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: What pity it is parental joys ſhould be ſo frequently embittered!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Never, here. No tyranny, no ſuſpicion, here. We know from whom we derive—Affection, expanſion of heart are our inmates: not trick, jealouſy, and concealment.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (Aſide) How will he ſupport it?—There is one fatal, yet univerſal, intruder. Love—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Diſturbs the peace of moſt fathers, but not mine. Were the daughter of Cam—Were my daughter in love, I ſhould be her firſt confidant.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And are you then ſo little read in the human heart, and its terrors; eſpecially the female heart?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Alarmed) Do theſe queſtions point at me?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Be calm. Tell me; how would you act ſhould a young man of rank demand your daughter's hand?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Refuſe him. Not but Paulina might unbluſhingly have placed her ſtool beſide the canopies of princes, had not I, her father, been unjuſtly forced to handle bruſhes!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And is that a ſtain?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Indelible! So 'tis thought.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: By prejudice and folly.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Your brother is a youth of ten thouſand: I reſpect and love his virtues: yet, were even he to aſk my Paulina, he would meet a denial.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Shall I ſtand at humble diſtance in the preſence of him by whom I ought to be treated with paternal reſpect; and crouch, and bend, when it might become me to exert the influence of reaſon, that I might prevent or redreſs error; and thus meanly deſert both duty and ſelf-eſteem?—There are nobility of birth and nobility of heart: the former but few enjoy; the latter many a poor and many a neglected man, in common with myſelf, poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Well, ſir, poſſeſſing that nobility, the other is a trifling want.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: 'Tis a want unknown to me: I am—

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Sir?— (Aſide) One effort more—You are acquainted with Sir Gregory Oldwort?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Indignantly) Forbear to mention him!—Your pardon!—His name is poiſon to me.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Hateful! Tyrannical!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Proudly) My name is Craig Campbell.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Heavens! Campbell!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: By marriage, I am his brother.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: 'Tis eighteen years ſince laſt I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: He is my uncle.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Pauſe) And Seymour your brother?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Yes. Nay more the lover of—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Be firm.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Paulina.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Thunder ſtrike!

div.head: SCENE XII. Enter NANNETTE: in great diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ah! Vhere is mit my maitreſſe; my Paulina? Vas ſhe not be come back?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (With terror) Is ſhe not within?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mon dieu, no! I am fear—! Mr. Seymour—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am ſee her run out; und I am run out too; und den ſhe is gone; und den I am be here, und be dere, und be every vhere, mitout I find her.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: A thouſand horrors ruſh upon me!—If Seymour have ſeduced my Paulina; have—Oh!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Heavens! Mr. Campbell! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ah ma pauvre maitreſſe! Mine friend! Mine ſhile! Vat ſhall I vill do? [Exit.

div.head: SCENE XIII. Changes to the Drawing-room of Lady FANCOURT:
div.stage: Her ladyſhip ſeated at a table.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I cannot forget her! A form ſo intereſting, a mind ſo capacious, courage ſo chaſtened, yet ſo unconquerable—! And muſt they marry? Has ſhe no equal? Are riches, rank, and Lady Fancourt ſo poor a counterpoiſe? Marry? It muſt not, ſhall not—ought not to be. (Noiſe without)

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: (Without) You muſt not, madam!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I will! I will!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Bleſs me!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Let me paſs! I will ſee her! I will!

div.head: SCENE XIV. Enter PAULINA: runs diſtractedly and throws herſelf at the feet of Lady FANCOURT.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Hear me, madam! I'll never quit this place till you have heard have granted my prayer.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Reſtore him to me! Reſtore him to me!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My all! My heaven on earth! He is mine!—I am a wretched diſtracted creature; once the happieſt of women!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Forbear!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You ſhall not go! He is mine! Saints and angels bear witneſs, he is mine! You have ſtolen him from me; deprived me of his heart; robbed me of the wealth of worlds!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Are you frantic?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Would I were! But ſoon I ſhall be. Give me my Seymour!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I give?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: To take my life were little. Oh, madam, you are noble; your anceſtors no doubt were magnanimous; but is it noble, is it magnanimous, to rob a poor lunatic creature of the only treaſure ſhe has on earth?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Be calm.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Calm! And loſe my Seymour? Never! Never! Madneſs is all I have to hope!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Riſe, I ſay! Leave me!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I will not riſe; I will not quit this ſpot! What are your rights? Do they equal oaths, regiſtered in heaven? Are they as ſacred?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: She is here! This muſt be her.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Inſufferable!—Relieve me, Lady Louiſa, from this frantic woman!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Wildly to Lady Louiſa) Have you ſeen my Seymour?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: You ſeem alarmed?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Never in my life was ſo aſſaulted; ſo overpowered! Pray look to her—Or call for aid—I cannot ſupport it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Do you know him? Hither I came to redemand my own! Here! Here they have robbed me of all that was moſt precious!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: My dear girl, pray ſit down!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: If you know him, I charge you, in the name of all that is holy, reſtore him to me!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Be pacified; I promiſe you ſhall ſee him again.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Do you promiſe?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I ſhall ſee him?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Half franticly) Promiſe? Promiſe?—Promiſes are hourly broken! You are not man? You are not a promiſe-breaker?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Quiet this agitation: you ſhall ſee him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Then you are an angel▪ ſent from heaven!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Mr. Seymour promiſed you marriage?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Earth and heaven heard his oaths! I am ſure he loves me! No; he cannot be perjured! Cruel parents only can oppoſe our bliſs!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: What if the marriage ſhould make him wretched?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Impoſſible! Impoſſible! Do I not know how I ſhould cheriſh how I ſhould adore him; how I ſhould ſtudy day and night for his happineſs?—He tells me he has a generous ſiſter—Oh! Could I but ſee her; could I but ſpeak to her!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I am that ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Falling on her knees and claſping her hands) Mercy!—Mercy!—Oh, have mercy on a poor diſtracted wretch.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Where is my child? Where is my Paulina?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Terrified ſinks on a ſopha) My father's voice!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Have I found thee? Come! Come to thy wretched father!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Be not too haſty, ſir!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Deteſted be the arts that have ſeduced my child!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Paſſion may increaſe cannot correct error. Mr. Seymour—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: A father's malediction purſue him!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (With ſudden and exceſſive energy) Hear not, oh mercy omnipotent, hear not a father's curſe!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: If you love your daughter, be patient. Her paſſions are not in a ſtate to be ſported with. 'Tis growing late; I will convey her home; ſleep will ſooth and reſtore her.

div.head: SCENE I. The Drawing-room of Lady FANCOURT.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: IS Lady Fancourt riſen?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Yes; and has enquired for you: appears much diſturbed, and reſolves again to viſit Paulina.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: For what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I wiſh I knew. Her ſurprize was great, and I fear painful, when ſhe heard of your relationſhip to Paulina. Dear girl! My heart yearns to her! You have ſeen her?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Yes, laſt night.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: And again pledged your fidelity?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Oh, with ten thouſand new endearments! Do you blame me?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Blame? Noble-minded, much injured girl! Still I dread the unfeeling Sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: And I. But there is the ſtrangeſt accident—He yeſterday ſat for his picture to my uncle Campbell!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: What without knowing each other?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Yes: and is to ſit again this morning—But his motive!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I tremble to diſcover, yet am on the rack till I know. Be the conſequences what they will, I am determined rather to relinquiſh life than Paulina. I wiſh therefore to avoid Lady Fancourt, till her mind is more calm.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Away then. I will be ready, if any thing ſhould happen.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: I dread her, I dread my uncle, nay I dread Mr. Campbell. The proſpect before us is terrific; but we muſt on—Be it as it will, you ſhall ſhare my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Generous Charles! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. The Painting-room.
div.stage: Sir GREGORY ſitting to CRAIG for his portrait.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Then you think the men of former ages were guilty of as great vices as thoſe of the preſent?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p:
Keep your mouth▪ ſhut—Greater: but they did not make a ſyſtem of vice; they were hurried into it by their paſſions. Theirs were the crimes of men. There is a diſgraceful a contemptible meanneſs in the vices, as well as the perſons of
the preſent puny race; and neither their paſſions nor their bodies have ſufficient proweſs to make them commit acts, that can entitle them to reſpect.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Riſes with animation) If they fight a duel, it is not in the heat of anger, and deſire of revenge; but it is done with as much ceremony and civility as if they were going to walk a minuet, or ſip a diſh of tea: ay and as little danger, too; for, as they manage the matter, there is ten times more terror in a crabtree cudgel than in lead and ſteel.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Why as to the merit, or virtue, of fighting duels, either in the old mode or the new, I believe we had better not talk of that.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: The veſtiges of ancient independence are wearing away. It makes my very heart ache to ſee the poor remains of towers, that once defied the fury of tyrants, and the war of elements, lye mouldering in ruins.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: If we erect a building, now, it is in ſuch a light, frippery, unſubſtantial ſtyle, that a piſtol bullet would demoliſh it. A caſtle of cobwebs, ſpun in July, and bruſhed away in November.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sir, you are a man of ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: And, as to our commerce, we have poiſoned the people with our teas, ſpices, and ſpirits. We ſend to China for pipkins, to Hudſon's Bay for cat's ſkins, to Venice for window alias vice blinds, and to Leghorn for toothpicks and fiddleſtrings: and, that the lower part of the community may not have the power to reproach and deſpiſe their leaders, vice, diſeaſe, and deſtruction are imported in ſhip loads, and parceled out in pennyworths.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sir, your converſation pleaſes me. Hem! When will your daughter be within?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Preſently, preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad to ſee if ſhe be as handſome as you have painted her.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Painted! Where are the colours that can equal Paulina?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Hay! Is her name Paulina?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Certainly. Why not?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Huſh! Did not I hear a noiſe?—Have you many viſitors?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Very few. I have not been long in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Where does that door go to?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: My daughter's bedroom.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I don't chooſe to be ſeen. If any body ſhould come, I'll ſtep in there.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Will you? You muſt aſk my leave, firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I wiſh ſhe would come! I am quite impatient to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Indeed! He's a whimſical old fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Liſtening and ſuſpecting) Hay?—No—Nothing—If ever you ſhould meet me in the ſtreet, take no notice of me.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Notice you! Sir, I notice no man who is unwilling to notice me. (A loud rapping at the ſtreet door)

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Oh, the devil!—Who's there?—Quick! Quick! My hat, and cloak!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Does he think I am his footman?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I would not be ſeen for a thouſand pounds! Can't you let me in there?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I tell you, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Have you no back way?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Back!—What do you take us for; coiners, or courtiers? We dare daylight; and, though poor, look the world in the face.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, miſter, what dark ſtairs you have!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: If you had ſent me notice of your coming, ſir, I would have had them lighted.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Anon! What were you pleaſed to remark, miſter? (Seeing Sir Gregory, in his cloak and ſlouched hat) What ſtrange animal have we here?—I think I have ſomewhere ſeen ſuch an apparition before! (Walks round and ſurveys Sir Gregory) I beg your pardon, miſter! (Sir Gregory feigns a violent cough, and pulls his hat cloſer over his eyes)

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Are you ill, ſir?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Laying hold of him) Ay, are you ill, ſir? (Sir Gregory twiſts himſelf angrily from Muſcadel and continues coughing)

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Aſide, to Mr. Craig) I'll wait below, in Mrs. Wilkins' parlour, till he is gone. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: As you pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Viewing the portrait) So, ſo! My old friend, Sir Gregory!—Tolerably hit off, egad. (To Craig) Why, you ſeem to have a knack, miſter—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Offended) Sir! I am not uſed to ſuch freedoms!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Impertinent and tetchy! I'll play him off. (Aloud) I ſay, miſter—What is your name?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: My name, ſir, is Craig.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Examining the picture) A very common name, in Wales.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Scotland, you mean.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I like your manner: you ſhall take me, miſter—Jones.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Increaſing anger) My name is Craig.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You are right. But I will be taken in profile, miſter—Jones.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Sir, I ſaid Craig.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Yes, there was Jones of Flintſhire, colonel of the Welch Fuzileers: very much of a gentleman, and ruined more farmer's daughters than any ten men in the regiment. I ſuppoſe you are his natural ſon, miſter—Jones.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Enraged) Sir!—I know nothing of Jones, Flintſhire colonels, or Welch Fuzileers: my name is—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: True. And ſo the colonel put you to a painter? A ſlight premium, and a quick riddance. He managed his pleaſures with economy.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Is he mad, or deaf?—I am afraid, ſir, I did not ſpeak loud enough! My name is Craig! I never—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Stopping his ears and ſtaring at him) I know it, miſter—Jones. The colonel told me the whole ſtory. Your mother was the daughter of a Denbighſhire drover, who dealt largely in potatoes, pigs, and poultry. A deviliſh handſome huſſey! The colonel was fond of her, brought her to town, and for a whole winter cut a high figure with her.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: With my mother, ſir?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: She was the belle of the day, miſter—Jones. She had my approbation, and I had a penchant for her myſelf.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: For my mother, ſir?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: The colonel was never married, but I have known ſeveral of his natural children, and they were all geniuſes. So you ſhall take my profile, miſter—Jones.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I have a great mind to knock him down!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Apropos. Have not you a ſmart kind of a daughter, miſter—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Continued paſſion) Jones. Yes.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ha!—Tolerably handſome (Turning his back) and well grown, miſter—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Turning back to back) Jones. Yes.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Turning half round) You have been bred to a pretty profeſſion, miſter—!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (Turning to face him) Jones. No.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Taking ſnuff and ſtaring) An't pleaſe you—?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I WAS BRED TO THE MOST USELESS, AND OFTEN THE MOST WORTHLESS, OF ALL PROFESSIONS; THAT OF A GENTLEMAN. See Preface.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Gadſo, miſter—!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I ſuſpect you have been bred to the ſame. So you will get your profile taken by whom you pleaſe, except by me, miſter—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Singing) La, la, la, la, la. The drapory is tolerable.

div.head: SCENE V. Enter PAULINA and NANNETTE.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: There's the door, ſir.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: La, la, la, la, la. The colouring not amiſs.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You ſeem ruffled, ſir?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Do you ſee that biped, Paulina?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: That thing pretends to have had an amour with my mother!

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha! (Turning his glaſs to Paulina) Upon my honour!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: The moſt impenetrable coxcomb—!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Infinitely beyond my expectations!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Firſt baptizing and then baſtardizing me!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: She is really ſtriking!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: A fop!—I would toſs him out of the window—! There's another odd fellow below, who is waiting to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Aſide to Paulina) C'eſt lui.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) What's this? Some ſecret? Seymour, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Who is he, ſir?

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Aſide to Paulina, Muſcadel liſtening) Mon dieu! 'Tis dee Chevalier Oldvort! C'eſt l'oncle!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Hay! Oldwort! Uncle!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: He won't tell his name. I am afraid his conſcience is none of the beſt, he is ſo fearful of being ſeen, or known.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Yes, yes; 'tis Sir Gregory! The old fox!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: I'll ſend him up to you. (Turning to Muſcadel) Come, ſir.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Eying the pictures) La, la, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I will go to him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: No, no— (Louder) Miſter—Jones!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: La, la, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (very loud) This way if you pleaſe, miſter—Jones.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) The fellow is determined; but I'll give him the ſlip. I'll know what's going on. La, la, la, la, la. Your very humble—miſter—

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Jones. [Exeunt Craig and Muſcadel.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why am I thus agitated? Too much al ready I have been the creature of paſſion; ſhaken by terror, actuated by ſelf. Oh! 'Tis unworthy! Yet ſtill and ſtill my fears ſubdue my better reaſon!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am vill be ſo happy! L'oncle come and make a lofe mit you, und you make a lofe mit die oncle, c'eſt tout naturel, und den! Ah! je ſuis extaſié!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My mother's perſecutor and my father's bitter foe: ſhould I ſo remember him? That were unjuſt. What he is, not what he has been, is the true queſtion. But there's the doubt! Why does he ſeek me? With what intent? He knows not who I am! Appearances are all ſuſpicious! Yet why this culpable propenſity to condemn unheard? 'Tis pernicious! 'Tis hateful! Why not hope the beſt?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He come! Retirez vous un moment: vite, vite! [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: So, ſo! There they go! I may chance to make ſome notable diſcoveries here. If they would but ſerve me with Lady Fancourt!—She has uſed me vilely! But no matter—Time has produced ſtrange things, and may again—This Sir Gregory! The old poacher! His portrait the pretence! The rival of his nephew! Yet as cynical ſupercilious and ſurly as if he were a ſaint. (Liſtens) He is coming (Looking round) Why, ay; theſe pictures are moſt convenient hiding places. (Muſcadel goes behind pictures)

div.head: SCENE VIII. Enter Sir GREGORY: with his cloak and hat on, firſt looking in, then advancing cautiouſly.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Hey dey! Here is nobody here! (Tries Paulina's door)

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Yes but there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p:
Locked faſt. (Returns to the entrance door and calls) Miſs!—Young lady!—I am afraid
this painting room is too public. I am glad I eſcaped that fop Muſcadel.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Very well!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: He is a moſt vain, impertinent, prating coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Mighty well!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: With leſs underſtanding than an owl by daylight.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Go on!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: More impudence than a croſs-examining lawyer.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) That's a lie, however.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: And as many antics as a dancing dog.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) You ſhall pay for this!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Calling, yet afraid of being heard) Mrs. Wilkins!—I would not have been diſcovered by him for a kingdom!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) I'll tickle you!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I hope I run no riſk here. Malicious tongues are always buſy; and a good character is like a gameſter's money, very difficult to keep, and when loſt ſtill more difficult to regain—Miſs! (Calling)—Here's ſomebody! (Hurries on his cloak)

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Aſide) Yet, not yet firm! Still in trepidation.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My father told me—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Throwing off his cloak) She's an angel! An angel! (Shuts the door)

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Bad, bad!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p:
Hem! Young lady—What carnation in her cheeks!—I have done myſelf the honour to
—That is, Mrs. Wilkins— (Continually turning to watch the entrance door).

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Aſide) My fears are too true!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: The fineſt eyes I ever beheld!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Peeping) The old ſinner!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I have an ambition to be better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Aſide) Fie! What looks! Alas, thus the little hope I had is flown.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What paſſion in her features! What modeſty! I love modeſty.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) As a hawk does a dove, to be the death of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: You are a moſt ſweet enchanting girl, and I hope you have a compaſſionate boſom.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Aſide) How tenfold ugly is vice coupled with age!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I'm ſure you have—Won't you ſpeak to me?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) The carnal old coaxer!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Aſide) My recollection fails me! How ſhould I anſwer him? Ought hoary ſeduction like this to paſs unreproved?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Don't be abaſhed. You can't think how kind I will be to you! (Muſcadel in moving throws down a picture) What's that? (Snatching up his cloak)

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Oh what an eternal tormentor is a guilty conſcience!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I ſee nothing!—Perhaps it was that picture? (Putting down his cloak) Ay! I will be ſo kind! I will dandle you, and fondle you, and fold you to my arms; ay, and wrap you in my very heart!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Like a diamond in wool, egad.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Do you think you could feel any partiality in favour of a middle aged gentleman, like me?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Aſide) He is my uncle. What then? Can relationſhip change the eternal eſſence of virtue? What are perſons? Guilt is ever guilt, and ever odious.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What elegance of form!—If I could but have the happineſs to win and wind myſelf into your affections (Taking hold of her hand)

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Forbear!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) So, ſo!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What? You! At theſe years! You! The inflexible perſecutor of venial errors; indulging deſtructive and hateful paſſions of your own, ſelfwilled inexorable and cruel to the very virtues of others; ſternly robing yourſelf in the tyrannous authority of cuſtom, forgetting the beneficence of juſtice—

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Heydey!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Were theſe, meanwhile, your ſecret practices? I came eagerly wiſhing to have called you by the endearing name of uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Uncle?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My heart beat high with the hope that age had increaſed your wiſdom, that your affections were ſoftened, and that you were become the friend of the unfortunate, the guide of the feeble, and the conſolation of the fallen.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Uncle?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No—Here all ſuch claims end. Henceforth they are forgotten. Farewell. There is no relationſhip between us. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE X. Sir GREGORY, and MUSCADEL.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Very odd.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p:
I'm in amaze—'Tis unaccountable—
Relationſhip!—Uncle!—Siſter! (Muſcadel purpoſely throws down the eaſel) Mercy on me!—Let me begone. (Puts on his cloak and hat) Her diſcourſe was very ſtrange—It has petrified me! (Going) I wiſh I was ſafe at home!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Sir Gregory!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul!—What's that?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Sir Gregory!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Am I bewitched? (Sees Muſcadel and begins to cough)

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Stop, ſtop, baronet! Coughing won't do: you can't eſcape this time. (Running and ſeizing him)

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I muſt beg, ſir—!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Come, come, unmaſk!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I inſiſt, ſir—!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh! What you won't know me?

div.head: SCENE XI. Enter Mrs. WILKINS: in a fright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh lord, Sir Gregory! What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What's the matter, woman? Is there an earthquake? I was half terrified to death before; would you kill me quite?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Dear me! Here's Lady Fancourt again!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: As true as I am a woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Let me begone!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Oh lord! You can't, Sir Gregory: ſhe is ſpeaking at the ſtairfoot with Miſs Paulina, and they are coming up in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What will become of me? Don't betray me, Mr. Muſcadel! (Extreme trepidation) For heaven's ſake, don't betray me!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Follow my example; hide behind theſe pictures. There's your own placed ready for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: She is bringing Miſs Paulina up here, to talk with her.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ah, ha! I ſhall be glad to ſee how her ladyſhip's jealouſy works (Goes up to Sir Gregory) Are you ſafe?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: (Peeping) Be true to me; don't diſcover me and I'll be your everlaſting friend. I'll bring you into parliament: you ſhall ſit for my vacant borough.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Cloſe, cloſe! (Coming forward) I know you, Mammon! You will tell a different tale tomorrow. I'm a coxcomb, am I? I'll puniſh you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: This way, your ladyſhip!

div.head: SCENE XII. Enter Lady FANCOURT followed by PAULINA.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Can you gainſay it?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I have done you, madam, no intentional wrong.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: No wrong? Have you not convinced me, in my own deſpite, that riches, rank, and power are feeble arms, oppoſed to the energies of mind and virtue?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Behind) How?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I, who thought not meanly of myſelf, have you not proved you are my ſuperiour: and is that no wrong?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Perſecuted by fate, nurtured in diſtreſs, educated in obſcurity, deprived of reſources that had been laviſhed upon me, have you not diſplayed qualities, which, how can I hope to equal?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Dear lady!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Ineſtimable girl! You can make me only one amends—Think kindly of me and accept me for your admiring your dear your eternal friend! (Embrace)

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Upon my honour it is incredible, but here they are! (Wiping his eyes and looking for the tears)

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: From the firſt moment, my heart did you juſtice: it acknowledged your noble virtues—I will affect no inferiority of rank, for I feel none; but to call myſelf your equal in what alone is valuable—? I dare not!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Advancing) Have you no hartſhorn, Lady Fancourt?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Mr. Muſcadel!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Here I am. Like ſilence, I come when I am not called—I thought I had had enough of the dolefuls; but here do you come, as it were on purpoſe, to give me a double doſe.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Have you been very ſorrowful?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: As wretched, for theſe four and twenty hours, as a poet who has left off rhyming—As melancholy as a blind monkey.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Not pleaſed) Very pathetic, truly!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Changing his tone) Lady Fancourt, ſhall I tell you a ſecret? The only reſource I have had, againſt feelings the moſt acute and thoughts the moſt racking, has been levity that was but affected, and indifference that was all forced.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Mr. Muſcadel—I have not uſed you well (Holding out her hand)

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Seizing and kiſſing it) Raptures!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Eagerly) Dear madam, where is my father; where is my—couſin? Are they friends?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: You will rejoice to ſee how truly!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: But where is Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Hay?

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Charles has been home, but he is not there.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Aſide) I'm a lucky dog!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: By converſing with my brother, Mr. Campbell has diſcovered that he has been here.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide) Yes; and is here ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: 'Tis well Mr. Campbell does not ſuſpect on what errand!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Aſide to Sir Gregory) Hem!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: The licentiouſneſs of his practice makes his ſeverity doubly odious.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Take care what you ſay; he will hear you.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I wiſh he could!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nay, he is in the room!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Pointing to the portrait) There!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Come my ſweet Paulina (Going)

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Nay but you muſt not go till you have ſeen the pictures. I aſſure you, here are ſome very excellent originals, in the room! (Sir Gregory occaſionally peeps and ſupplicates by ſigns)

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Ay?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: You have never ſeen a finer exhibition.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Or a more pleaſant one.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I ſee nothing extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh but follow me and you ſhall ſee! You know theſe, Lady Louiſa? (Holding up the cloak and hat of Sir Gregory)

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: It ſeems like my uncle's cloak!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: That's a trifle! You ſhall ſee more preſently. (Removes a picture) How do you like that?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: It ſeems very good.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Removing another). And that?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Indeed I am no judge.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: (Removing a third) And that?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Better than the laſt.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ay but here! Here's the beſt of all! (Diſcovering Sir Gregory)

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: Heaven preſerve me!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: There's an exhibition for you! There's nature! There's life! There's expreſſion!—Shall I have the borough, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I hope you'll have a halter!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Why, Sir Gregory, is this the way you ſit for your portrait?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ay! Is not the attitude ſtriking? Graceful as a baboon on the back of a bear!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: This is very extraordinary! Pray tell us—

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Sir Gregory has been at his needle work.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I wiſh you had been at the devil!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: I'm a fop, an owl, a dancing dog, hay, Sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: You are as great a cut-throat—!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: As cold water in winter.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: And I hope as wholeſome a one, too.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: (To Lady Fancourt) This is the moment for reconciliation! I will go down for my brother and uncle.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: A lucky thought! Do.

div.head: SCENE XIV. Sir GREGORY, MUSCADEL, Lady FANCOURT, PAULINA.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Stay, niece; I'll go with you. (Going)

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: No, no, Sir Gregory; we can't ſpare you. Mr. Muſcadel!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Ay, ay; I'll guard the door.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: I find then, my dear Paulina, you have ſeen your uncle before?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Yes; the knight introduced himſelf: and faith ſhe read him a very pretty lecture: though egad her ſtyle was a little myſterious, for ſhe ſeemed able to give the whole ſcandalous chronicle of your private life—hay, Baronet?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Oh I defy her and the whole world. I am the carver of my own character, and cut it up neatly and accurately myſelf, that Malice may be out of countenance when ſhe attempts to hack it.—Come; ſhall I help you on with your cloak?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Curſe my cloak— (Aſide) And you too!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Sir Gregory has no more need of a cloak,

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Egad that's true. Come, come, cheer up, knight: this is the luckieſt day of your life; for, now you have loſt your character, you may ſtare the world in the face, and ſin hereafter without caution.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (To Muſcadel) Pardon me, ſir, but I muſt intreat you to forbear. Who among us but errs? To oppreſs the oppreſſed would be malice, not juſtice.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes, I do hear!

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: And do you not bluſh a little?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Perhaps I do that too.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p:
Let me, ſir, intreat your forgiveneſs; I am the cauſe of this: I behaved ill; I left you indignantly inſtead of remonſtrating with candour, and indulged reſentment when I ought to have exerted
benevolence. But I am young and ſhall know better in time.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: You are a miracle! And I am aſhamed of myſelf.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Belial I find has a ſpark of grace left.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Incomparable Paulina!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Will you not forgive me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I cannot forgive myſelf, child.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: For having been found out.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Be as happy, not as you deſerve, but as I can make you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: (Kneels) Oh, ſir—!

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Riſe, Paulina, riſe.

div.head: SCENE XV. Enter SEYMOUR, CRAIG CAMPBELL, and Lady LOUISA.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My life! Running into each other's arms.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: My Seymour!

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: My ſoul!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Art thou mine? Art thou mine?

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: Everlaſtingly!

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: (To Sir Gregory) Sir!

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Huſh! No frowning.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Recrimination is no cure. I muſt abjure my prejudices; do you ſuffer your reſentments to ſleep. Henceforth let us be friends.

sp.speaker: Craig.
sp.p: Nay, if generoſity, mutual friendſhip, and free equal intercourſe be your purpoſe, Craig Campbell, though a painter and a hireling, will do you no ſhame.

sp.speaker: Lady L.
sp.p: I then at laſt am the only outcaſt—Will you not pardon me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes, yes; all is forgotten.

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p:
How kind your moody rulers are, when once their own rogueries are de • ected— (To Lady Fancourt) Muſt we not ſympathize with the reſt
and be as happy as we can? (Tenderly) Muſt we not?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: (Smiling) Why would you, now you have been my confidant, would you dangle after me again?

sp.speaker: Muſc.
sp.p: Moſt willingly. Like the beaſts after Orpheus—You have a muſeum of them, and I am the moſt admired monſter in the collection.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: You are a pleaſant animal.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why this is true delight—Love, friendſhip, and benevolence, catching and ſpreading from mind to mind, from heart to heart; modeling the young, melting the old, and harmonizing all. May the principle and the practice become univerſal!
